name: Spring SOP
description: The Spring SOP deforms and moves the input geometry using spring "forces" on the edges of polygons and on masses attached to each point.
summary: The Spring SOP deforms and moves the input geometry using spring "forces" on the edges of polygons and on masses attached to each point.

parameters.name: Preroll Time
parameters.label: Preroll Time
parameters.description:
From Derivative
		
		
		
		
		Jump to navigation
		Jump to search
		
The Spring  deforms and moves the input geometry using spring "forces" on the edges of polygons and on masses attached to each point.		
Geometry is deformed using forces that simulate simple physics on the points and edges. A simulated "mass" is assigned to each point. Its primitive edges act as "springs" which oppose the forces, and pull the points back toward their original positions. When the springs are stretched by the forces, they try to pull the points back. The points do not stop moving when they return to their original positions, however, but continue to oscillate because of their mass, until the oscillation dies out.			
Forces which act upon the points are as follows:			

external force (gravity)
wind (similar to external force)
turbulence (chaotic forces)The greater the drag value, or smaller the mass, the faster the oscillation dies out.
springSOP_Class

Contents
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 





  timepreroll - How many seconds of the simulation to bypass, after the reset time is reached. For example, if you put the number 33 into this field (and reset is at $TSTART), frame one will show the simulation that was at a time of 33 seconds. In other words, the first thirty-two seconds have been bypassed, and the time at thirty-three seconds is shifted to frame one. The first thirty-two seconds must still be calculated in order to compute the status of the points, so you will notice some delay upon reset.


		
  timeinc - The  parameter determines how often to cook the . By default, this parameter is set to 1/$. This means that the  will cook once for every frame. When complex dynamics are involved, the  may require more frequent cooking for increased mathematical accuracy. To get sub-frame accuracy in the cooking, set the  to something smaller than 1/$ . For example, setting the  to 0.5/$ will mean that the  gets cooked twice for every frame.	
Note: Never set this parameter greater than 1/$.


		
  accurate - This option makes the nodes move more accurately between frames by calculating their trajectories for fractional frame values.


		
  attractmode -  - Describes how attractor points are assigned to each particle.

 all - All point attractors affect all particles (or points). single - When enabled, each particle is assigned a single attractor point, and is affected by only that point. Assignment is done by point number modulo the total number of attractor points.
		
  reset - While On resets the spring effect of the .


		
  resetpulse - Instantly reset the spring effect.





  external -  - Forces of gravity acting on the points. When drag is zero, the points can accelerate with no limit on their speed.

 externalx - externaly - externalz -
		
  wind -  - Wind forces acting on the points. Similar to external force. Using wind (and no other forces, such as turbulence), the points will not exceed the wind velocity.

 windx - windy - windz -
		
  turb -  - The amplitude of turbulent (chaotic) forces along each axis. Use positive values, if any.

 turbx - turby - turbz -
		
  period - A small period means that the turbulence varies quickly over a small area, while a larger value will cause points close to each other to be affected similarly.


		
  seed - Random number seed for the simulation.





  fixed - This is a point group. All points in the point group will remain unaffected by the forces. Also see the Group SOP for notes on how to specify point ranges.


		
  revertfixed - Determines whether or not points in the  group should be moved to the positions of the corresponding points in the Source geometry.


		
  copygroups - Determines if the Spring  should copy groups from the Source geometry at each frame. This lets you specify the name of an animating group in the  field, and the contents of this group will be kept up to date.


		
  domass - When selected, the  is computed for the deforming geometry.


		
  mass -  of each point. Heavier points take longer to get into motion, and longer to stop.


		
  dodrag - When selected, the geometry is deformed by the  attribute.


		
  drag -  of each point.


		
  springbehavior -  - How the springs will behave:

 hooke - Springs will work according to Hooke's Law. This is generally more stable than .Hooke's Law: Force = Displacement  Spring constant normalize - Similar to  except that the displacement is normalized to the original length of the Spring.
		
  springk - The spring constant. How tight the springs are. Increase this value to make the springs tighter and thus make the object more rigid. As this number becomes higher, the springs can oscillate out of control. Decrease the  if this happens.


		
  tension - The Initial k constant of the geometry before being deformed by the spring operation.





  limitpos -  - The points will bounce off the limit planes when it reaches them. The six limit plane fields define a bounding cube. The default settings are one thousand units away, which is very large. Reduce the values to about one to see the effect.

 limitposx - limitposy - limitposz -
		
  limitneg -  - The points will bounce off the limit planes when it reaches them. The six limit plane fields define a bounding cube. The default settings are one thousand units away, which is very large. Reduce the values to about one to see the effect.

 limitnegx - limitnegy - limitnegz -
		
  hit -  - Control over what happens when the geometry hits either the six collision planes or the collision object. The options are:

 bounce - Geometry will bounce upon contact with the Collision input. stick - Geometry will stick to the Collision input upon contact.
		
  gaintan - Friction parameters which can be regarded as energy-loss upon collision. The first parameter affects the energy loss (gain) perpendicular to the surface. 0 means all energy (velocity) is lost, 1 means no energy is lost perpendicular to surface. The second parameter is the energy gain tangent to the surface.


		
  gainnorm - Friction parameters which can be regarded as energy-loss upon collision. The first parameter affects the energy loss (gain) perpendicular to the surface. 0 means all energy (velocity) is lost, 1 means no energy is lost perpendicular to surface. The second parameter is the energy gain tangent to the surface.





 -
 -
 -

Extra Information for the Spring  can be accessed via an Info CHOP.



 - Number of points in this . - Number of primitives in this . - Number of particles in this . - Time spent in another thread updating geometry data on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time. - Time spent in another thread updating meta surface geometry data (such as metaballs or nurbs) on the  from the 's CPU data. As it is part of another thread, this time is not part of the usual frame time.
 - Number of times the operator has cooked since the process started. - Duration of the last cook in milliseconds. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the component timeline. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the absolute time. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator started cooking in the frame it was cooked. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator finished cooking in the frame it was cooked. - 1 if operator was cooked this frame. - Number of warnings in this operator if any. - Number of errors in this operator if any.
TouchDesigner Build: Latest\n2021.100002018.28070before 2018.28070
SOPs
• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • 

A Operator Family that reads, creates and modifies 3D points, polygons, lines, particles, surfaces, spheres and meatballs. Particles and point clouds are now done primarily on the GPU using TOPs.



The Frames-per-Second that TouchDesigner's Timeline runs at. Set with project.cookRate.



Each SOP has a list of Points. Each point has an XYZ 3D position value plus other optional attributes. Each polygon Primitive is defined by a vertex list, which is list of point numbers.



To "pulse" a parameter is to send it a signal from (1) an exported CHOP channel or (2) a python command or (3) a mouse click that causes a new action to occur immediately. A pulse via python is via the .pulse() function on a pulse-type parameter, such as Reset parameter in a Speed CHOP. A pulse from a CHOP is typically a 0 to 1 to 0 signal in an exported channel.



An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



The Graphics Processing Unit. This is the high-speed, many-core processor of the graphics card/chip that takes geometry, images and data from the CPU and creates images and processed data.








Retrieved from "https://docs.derivative.ca/index.php?title=Spring_SOP&oldid=27192"
		Category: SOPs

parameters.name: Turb Period
parameters.label: Turb Period
parameters.description: period - A small period means that the turbulence varies quickly over a small area, while a larger value will cause points close to each other to be affected similarly.

parameters.name: Seed
parameters.label: Seed
parameters.description: seed - Random number seed for the simulation.

parameters.name: Fixed Points
parameters.label: Fixed Points
parameters.description: fixed - This is a point group. All points in the point group will remain unaffected by the forces. Also see the Group SOP for notes on how to specify point ranges.

parameters.name: Fixed Points go to Source Positions
parameters.label: Fixed Points go to Source Positions
parameters.description: revertfixed - Determines whether or not points in the  group should be moved to the positions of the corresponding points in the Source geometry.

parameters.name: Copy Groups from Source
parameters.label: Copy Groups from Source
parameters.description: copygroups - Determines if the Spring  should copy groups from the Source geometry at each frame. This lets you specify the name of an animating group in the  field, and the contents of this group will be kept up to date.

parameters.name: Add Mass Attribute
parameters.label: Add Mass Attribute
parameters.description: domass - When selected, the  is computed for the deforming geometry.

parameters.name: Mass
parameters.label: Mass
parameters.description: mass -  of each point. Heavier points take longer to get into motion, and longer to stop.

parameters.name: Add Drag Attribute
parameters.label: Add Drag Attribute
parameters.description: dodrag - When selected, the geometry is deformed by the  attribute.

parameters.name: Drag
parameters.label: Drag
parameters.description: drag -  of each point.

parameters.name: Spring Behavior
parameters.label: Spring Behavior
parameters.description:
springbehavior -  - How the springs will behave:

 hooke - Springs will work according to Hooke's Law. This is generally more stable than .Hooke's Law: Force = Displacement  Spring constant normalize - Similar to  except that the displacement is normalized to the original length of the Spring.

parameters.name: Hooke's Law
parameters.label: Hooke's Law
parameters.description: hooke - Springs will work according to Hooke's Law. This is generally more stable than .Hooke's Law: Force = Displacement  Spring constant normalize - Similar to  except that the displacement is normalized to the original length of the Spring.

parameters.name: Spring Constant
parameters.label: Spring Constant
parameters.description: springk - The spring constant. How tight the springs are. Increase this value to make the springs tighter and thus make the object more rigid. As this number becomes higher, the springs can oscillate out of control. Decrease the  if this happens.

parameters.name: Initial Tension
parameters.label: Initial Tension
parameters.description: tension - The Initial k constant of the geometry before being deformed by the spring operation.

parameters.name: + Limit Plane
parameters.label: + Limit Plane
parameters.description:
limitpos -  - The points will bounce off the limit planes when it reaches them. The six limit plane fields define a bounding cube. The default settings are one thousand units away, which is very large. Reduce the values to about one to see the effect.

 limitposx - limitposy - limitposz -

parameters.name: X
parameters.label: X
parameters.description: limitposx - limitposy - limitposz -

parameters.name: - Limit Plane
parameters.label: - Limit Plane
parameters.description:
limitneg -  - The points will bounce off the limit planes when it reaches them. The six limit plane fields define a bounding cube. The default settings are one thousand units away, which is very large. Reduce the values to about one to see the effect.

 limitnegx - limitnegy - limitnegz -

parameters.name: X
parameters.label: X
parameters.description: limitnegx - limitnegy - limitnegz -

parameters.name: Hit Behavior
parameters.label: Hit Behavior
parameters.description:
hit -  - Control over what happens when the geometry hits either the six collision planes or the collision object. The options are:

 bounce - Geometry will bounce upon contact with the Collision input. stick - Geometry will stick to the Collision input upon contact.

parameters.name: Bounce on Contact
parameters.label: Bounce on Contact
parameters.description: bounce - Geometry will bounce upon contact with the Collision input. stick - Geometry will stick to the Collision input upon contact.

parameters.name: Gain Tangent
parameters.label: Gain Tangent
parameters.description: gaintan - Friction parameters which can be regarded as energy-loss upon collision. The first parameter affects the energy loss (gain) perpendicular to the surface. 0 means all energy (velocity) is lost, 1 means no energy is lost perpendicular to surface. The second parameter is the energy gain tangent to the surface.

parameters.name: Gain Normal
parameters.label: Gain Normal
parameters.description: gainnorm - Friction parameters which can be regarded as energy-loss upon collision. The first parameter affects the energy loss (gain) perpendicular to the surface. 0 means all energy (velocity) is lost, 1 means no energy is lost perpendicular to surface. The second parameter is the energy gain tangent to the surface.
